Apr 6

Brook Lopez — The (Offensive) Force Awakens

The Brooklyn Nets’ veteran center has developed into one of the most versatile big men in the entire NBA.

Brooklyn Nets big man (and franchise centerpiece) Brook Lopez is a big Star Wars fan. Here’s Brook engaging in a lightsaber duel with his twin Robin. His bobblehead this season was a Lopez-Wookie amalgamation. Last season, it was Lopez as a Jedi. In the Nets’ timeout video quizzes, Lopez named (non-canon) Star Wars Legends characters Lowbacca and Jacen Solo in his one-minute lightning round of naming characters. So yes, he’s a fan.

Like Luke Skywalker progressing through the original Star Wars trilogy, Lopez has continually developed throughout his nine years with the Nets. In his first eight seasons, he was a goofy, comic book loving post-up big man with a soft touch from anywhere inside the three-point line. In his ninth season in the NBA, Lopez has become a goofy, comic book loving offensive Swiss Army knife center.

Lopez’s offensive numbers show his impact. His ORPM of 1.45 only trails Karl-Anthony Towns and Marc Gasol, per ESPN. Per NBA Math, Lopez is responsible for 93.07 offensive points added, ranking above Carmelo Anthony and Anthony Davis, among others. While his defense has left a lot to be desired, he is not a complete liability on that end, as many have often labeled him.

Judging from his progress this season, Lopez’s offensive game seems limitless. Here’s what we’ve seen from Lopez this season, preceded by some Luke Skywalker quotes.

Inside the Brooklyn Nets’ March Mania
The Brooklyn Nets have had a solid March, improving in nearly every statistical category. What’s been the driving force…16winsaring.com

“I want to learn the ways of the Three”

This season, Lopez has made 132 three-point shots on 35.5% shooting from deep, prior to their Thursday matchup against the Chicago Bulls. He actually leads the Nets in three point shot attempts this season, with 369. That’s over 50 more attempts than Manhattan’s Unicorn, Kristaps Porzingis, and over 100 more attempts than Marc Gasol, another mid-career three-point shooting center.

Per Ben Nadeau of Basketball Insiders, Lopez is the third player in NBA history to make over 130 three-point field goals and block over 120 shots in a season. The other two are Rasheed Wallace (2005–2006) and Donyell Marshall (2003–2004).

Inside the Brooklyn Nets’ March Mania
The Brooklyn Nets have had a solid March, improving in nearly every statistical category. What’s been the driving force…16winsaring.com

Lopez isn’t just a corner or top of the key three-point shooter, like many big men with expanded shooting range. He can shoot it from anywhere, and from deep. Watch Lopez drill a three in front of Kristaps Porzingis here, about two giant steps away from the three-point line.

Lopez’s three-point shooting uptick has been well documented. But Brook hasn’t just become a great shooter — he’s become a more well-rounded offensive player as a whole. Even more interesting is Lopez’s improvement in other assets of his game.

“Your overconfidence (in defending me) is your weakness”

Despite his athletic limitations, Lopez is surprisingly nimble for his size. To compliment his three-point shot, he has added a pump-and-drive to his repertoire. The big man can take it all the way to the rim, launch a nifty floater, or shoot it off the dribble. Take a look…

This jumper, in particular, is one of my favorite unexpected Lopez buckets (I titled the video Lopez Curry Shot)…

On the season, Lopez is shooting 52.5% on 2.6 drives per game. That ranks him slightly ahead of guards like Goran Dragic (52.1%) and Damian Lillard (51.0%), per NBA.com/stats. That’s not an invitation for Lopez to become a point center, but he has been surprisingly efficient off the dribble, especially for a big man.

Even with his foray to the perimeter, Lopez has become a more efficient player in the paint. He shoots 71.9% on post-up attempts and 62.5% from within five feet, per basketball-reference. Coach Kenny Atkinson likes to run Flex screen action on out of bounds plays to free Lopez either deep in the post or in the mid-paint. Check out Isaiah Whitehead setting a great flex screen to set Lopez up for an open floater on the sideline out of bounds play.

Kenny Atkinson’s offense emphasizes attacking defenses. When looking to score, Lopez doesn’t just resort to shooting or post ups. Early criticism of his game stated that his moves looked robotic, and that his decision-making was premeditated. Lopez has become more fluid and more dynamic as a scorer this season. That’s evident with his moves off of the dribble and his improved efficiency in the post.

“Let go of your hate (and pass the ball)”

Nets fans will likely not remember the Lionel Hollins head coaching run fondly. Although the Nets made the playoffs (barely) in 2014–2015, Hollins’ run as head coach was marked by inconsistent play, questionable rotations, and throwing his players under the bus. But one of the few positive developments from the Hollins era was Brook Lopez’s progression as a passer.

Hollins essentially copy-and-pasted the Memphis Grizzlies playbook when joining the Nets. While the system may not have fit the Nets’ needs in 2014–2015, it allowed Lopez to do his best Marc Gasol impression. Gasol is one of the best big man passers in the league, assisting cutters and shooters in both the post and as a perimeter hand off man. Lopez showed his newfound passing prowess most notably with former Net Bojan Bogdanovic. The duo was a nice tandem in their two-and-a-half seasons as teammates. Here, Lopez finds Bogdanovic on a lob to the rim after receiving the high post pass.

Like the rest of his offensive game, Lopez’s passing has also diversified from simple two-man action. Part of his newfound comfort as an offensive player is the vision to find teammates around the court. Lopez previously struggled when doubled, often turning the ball over or forcing up a contested shot. Here, Lopez turns around in the post and quickly shovels a pass to a cutting Quincy Acy after sensing Jae Crowder shading for a double.

Lopez has a drive and kick game too. I can’t think of another big man that has that ability, especially those that are seven feet tall. In this flowing possession against the New York Knicks, the defense shuffles when Lopez rumbles into the lane. It allows Lopez to find Jeremy Lin, who takes it to the rim for an easy layup.

Now check out this perfect bounce pass to a cutting Lin for a layup against the Atlanta Hawks. He drives, pivots, surveys the defense, and finds the cutter. The Brook-Lin combo was surely part of the Nets’ big plans last offseason. Unfortunately, the two have played less than 40 games together.

Lopez is averaging 2.4 assists per game, and is responsible for 4.7 potential assists per game, via tracking data from NBA.com/stats. That number would be the best mark of his career, up from 2.0 assists last season. He may be averaging 2.5 turnovers per game, but his newfound ability to find teammates and act as an offensive cog is perfect for the Nets’ motion offense.

Trade chip or building block?

Brook Lopez has been the target of trade rumors for seemingly his whole career. A quick search of “Brook Lopez trade” on Google returns 855,000 results. Yet Lopez has remained a Net despite the rumors. He’s mere points away from passing Buck Williams as the Nets’ all-time leader in points. Lopez has been the lone constant for a franchise that has been through nine coaches, three home arenas, and hundreds of teammates since 2008. (Do you remember when Brook Lopez and Brandan Wright were teammates? Neither do I.)

Too Short On LeBron, Jay-Z In 2010: “I think he was thinking about signing LeBron and having him…
Oakland hip hop legend Too Short has been in the news the last couple of days because of his interview on the Scoop B…16winsaring.com

Now, there are several Lopez trade advocates. But Lopez’s value to the Nets may be more valuable than mid-first round picks. There is no center that can (realistically) be acquired by trade or draft that can match Lopez’s production. He may not be as valuable to other teams, but Lopez is consistent, and seemingly, still improving. Although he may have recently turned 29, his offensive game may not fall off a cliff. He relies on skill, rather than athleticism as an offensive force.

Additionally Lopez’s professionalism and consistency throughout franchise turmoil is a strong trait for a team trying to build a culture. Along with Jeremy Lin and Trevor Booker, Lopez is a young veteran that can guide teammates on-court and off. Lopez even took his teammates to Disney World! (And Disneyland too!) See, you don’t have to win a Super Bowl to go to Disney.

Brook Lopez’s offensive progression has been a sight to behold. He’s become a multi-faceted offensive weapon — quietly. Although the wins may not have been there this season, Lopez is a major factor in the Nets’ late-season upswing. While his future with Brooklyn may be opaque, he’s made his case as a Nets building block, showing that players can improve well into their careers. May The Force be with Brookie the Wookie. Cue the Star Wars music!
